snippet: The provision known as the “double Irish,” used by companies like Google to reduce their bills, has been under scrutiny from European Union regulators.
abstract: Ireland responds to criticism of its business-friendly tax arrangements by closing loophole used by multinational giants like Google; European Union and Obama administration have been increasingly vocal about tax-avoidance strategies of multinational firms and countries that enable them.

byline.original: By STEPHEN CASTLE and MARK SCOTT
byline.contributor: Patricia Cohen contributed reporting from New York, and James Kanter from Luxembourg.

lead_paragraph: The provision known as the “double Irish,” used by companies like Google to reduce their bills, has been under scrutiny from European Union regulators.

headline.main: Ireland to Phase Out ‘Double Irish’ Tax Break Used by Tech Giants
headline.print_headline: Under Fire, Ireland Is Set to Phase Out a Tax Break
